Before you start learning Japanese, first you need to know how they speak.
Japanese uses a lot of A, E, I, O and U and these sound different than they do in English

Our first lesson will be on learning to say A, I, U, E and O

Next lesson…

Sounds like the A in 'C-a-r' or 'A-wful'

Can you say A?

Imagine you've just thought of a great idea, telling everyone "Ah! That's it!"

Remember, vowel sounds always sound the same in Japanese. Not like English where the A sound in 'today' and the A sound in 'car' are different

Sounds like the English 'E'. Imagine the 'E' sound in Eel

It might be hard to remember because 'い' sounds like the English 'E', not 'I' but try to use that to help you. Remember that it's not the same and remember the eels

Sounds like 'oo'. Like seeing a gorgeous display happen in front of you. 
It is the same sound as the 'ou' in 'You'. 

'う' is the direct translation of our English 'U'. If you look closely you can see that 'う' looks like a 'U' on its side. Use this to help you remember.

Sounds like the 'E' in 'Egg'.

The symbol for this sound is 'え' which, when you look at it really hard, looks like a bird, an 'e'xotic bird. Use this to help you.

Sounds like 'oh', or like the 'O' in our English alphabet.

This is a simple one to remember. The symbol for this sound is 'お' and this symbol has a 'o' shape inside of it.
'O' is how it is pronounced in English and also how it looks in Japanese.

Now you can say the vowels, it's time to learn the words.

Here, you will learn the words for 4 animals which may be included in the test at the end.

Are you ready?

Do you recognise this creature? 

This is a cat. You or your friends may be living with one

In Japanese, a cat is 'Neko'.

Try saying this aloud, Neko.

What about this one, can you name it?

Rabbit, usually kept in huts filled with straw to keep them comfy. Sometimes you can see them in the wild.

The Japanese know rabbit as 'Usagi'.

Say it with me, Usagi.

This creature we know as a dog.

Dogs are friendly, loyal animals that love to go on walks and bring back sticks you throw for them.

In Japan, a dog is known as 'Inu'. This word may sounds a little familiar. This is because there is a type of dog called a 'Shiba Inu', meaning 'small dog' or 'shrub dog'

You may or may not recognise this creature. Can you guess what it is? It's a fox!

Foxes have been known to roam around cities or keep to themselves in the wild.

The fox in Japanese is known by 'Kitsune'. Say Kitsune aloud, Kitsune.

In this lesson, we will learn what you would call those around you.

This section can get a little confusing because it includes honorifics. 

This may sound like a scary word but we will only focus on the common ones used in conversation.

There are a lot of honorifics in Japanese. Honorifics are words that you put after a person's name and is a big part of everyday conversation, what you use depends on their position compared to you. This will make more sense later.

If you do not use honorifics or use the wrong one, you might insult the other person.

The four honorifics you will be taught today are -san, -chan, -senpai/-kohai and -sensei.

We will first learn about -san. San can be used in almost all conversations and more than likely not going to cause offense. San is used for your equals, if their position is the same as your. You might call your friends or other students in the same year -san.

San can also be used to call someone who you do not know or you do not know their position.

Chan has a cute meaning attached to it, a friendly meaning. You could call animals or pets -chan. You yourself might also be called -chan since it is typically used on young children. 
For example, you might call your cat Neko-chan or your dog Inu-chan

Chan can also be used between close friends or relatives. Calling your teacher, or someone you do not closely know, might offend them.

Senpai and Kohai are similar but different. Senpai is used for someone who is older than you or in a higher position than you. You would call older students -senpai.

Kohai is similar in the sense it is what Senpais would call you, or you would call people younger than you.

Senpai and Kohai can also be used alone, without a name attached.

Fourth and finally, there is -sensei. Sensei is used for people who have a massive amount of knowledge in what they know. Your teacher will be known as -sensei. Other people such as doctors, politicians and lawyers would be given the -sensei honorific.

However -sensei can also be used sarcastically too. You could call a friend -sensei when making a joke with them, as long as it does not offend them.
To see if we have remember what we have learned we shall answer some questions based on what we were taught in the earlier sections.
Well done! You have answered all the question! Please look forward to new lessons and new questions being added later on!.
